(Blue (light blue) and gray represent Fe and C atoms). Fig 1 Fig. 2 Six co-adsorption configurations of 2H and CO2 on Fe5C2(510) surface obtained after optimization. (blue: Fe; gray: C Fe5C2; red: O; white: H; black: C of CO2). Fig 2 Fig. 3 CO2 activation mechanisms and their corresponding reaction pathways. Fig 3 Fig. 4 The energy and structures for CO2 dissociation on Fe5C2(510) surface. (blue: Fe; gray: C in Fe5C2; red: O; white: H; black: C of CO2). State Key Laboratory of High-Efficiency Utilization of Coal and Green Chemical Engineering, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Ningxia University Yinchuan 750021 China The conversion of CO2 into high-value-added chemicals via the Fischer-Tropsch Synthesis (FTS) reaction has gathered a lot of attention. The surface oxygenation environment is a significant factor affecting the catalyst performance. In this work, spin-polarized density-functional theory calculations have been used to investigate the adsorption and reactions of CO2 and H to generate CH4 and CH3OH on Fe5C2(510) surfaces with varying OH* coverage. On the pure Fe5C2(510) surface, CO2 preferentially dissociates via direct dissociation, and the major C1 species generated is CH4. At low OH* coverage, the preferential pathway for CO2 dissociation changes from direct dissociation to the H-assisted route by the formation of COOH*. The major C1 product of the reaction in this state is transferred to CH3OH. In addition, CO2 hydrogenation reactions are facilitated by the OH* species. At high OH coverage, CO2 preferentially dissociates through the HCOO* intermediates. However, it appears that the CO2 hydrogenation reaction activity is suppressed. The results demonstrate that maintaining the surface environment with OH* and H* could be an indispensable measure to obtain the target product in the iron-based CO2 Fischer-Tropsch Synthesis system. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Surface OH Iron-based catalyst CO2 hydrogenation Fischer-Tropsch Synthesis (FTS) Surface environment Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction As the energy industry expands, the concentration of greenhouse gases (GHGs), such as CO2, continues to rise in the atmosphere, resulting in a slew of environmental issues [1]. Despite significant efforts over the past decades, controlling CO2 concentrations and converting them efficiently remain tough [2]. The conversion of CO2 into high-value chemical feedstocks via the Fischer-Tropsch Synthesis (FTS) reaction has gathered a lot of attention [3–7]. And this synthetic technology, which converts greenhouse gases into high-value fuels and chemicals, contributes to reducing carbon emissions and achieving resource recycling [8]. Fe, Co, Ni, and noble metals are frequently used as active metals in Fischer-Tropsch catalysts [9,10]. Iron-based catalysts can be utilized to produce a mixture of hydrocarbon fuels, including a significant amount of branched alkanes [11]. Additionally, they have higher Reverse Water-Gas Shift (RWGS) reactivity than Co or Ru catalysts, making them very attractive for coal-to-liquid fuel, biomass-to-liquid fuel (BTL) technologies, [12,13] and CO2 conversion. [14] To create Fe-based catalysts with significant catalytic activity, some modification is usually required [15]. Effective strategies to modify the catalytic performance of iron-based catalysts include adding promoters (such as K and Mn) [16,17] and adopting other active components (such as Cu, Pd, Co, and Ni) [18,19]. Iron carbides were found in used Fe2O3 catalysts converting CO2 to hydrocarbons, indicating that the catalysts underwent a phase shift during the process [20,21]. Iron carbide has been identified as the primary active phase of Fe-based catalysts [22,23], while the other types of active phases are their zero-valent monomers [24,25]. Various stable iron carbide phases have been seen in experimental experiments, including h-Fe7C3, χ-Fe5C2, θ-Fe3C, ε'-Fe2.2C, and ε-Fe2C phases [26,27]. Extensive experimental and theoretical studies have demonstrated that the Fe5C2 phase possesses good activity for CO hydrogenation [28,29]. Recent experimental and theoretical investigations have also indicated that the Fe5C2 phase exhibits favorable performance for CO2 hydrogenation [10,30]. During the reaction process, the generation of surface O* species occurs concurrently with the hydrogenation of CO2 [31,32]. Because oxygen species (O* species) is not a feedstock for hydrocarbon generation, High coverage of O* species on the catalyst surface competes with the adsorption of reactants (CO2 and H2) and the desired products (lower carbon hydrocarbons), so O* species are regarded as a byproducts that should be quickly removed during the conversion of CO2 to hydrocarbons. [33,34]. However, comprehensive theoretical research on the impact of O* and its derivatives on the elementary reactions of CO2 hydrogenation on the catalyst surface is still needed. In the former research, the Fe5C2(510) surface has frequently been employed because of its superior FTS reactivity [35]. Since it has a high thermodynamic stability and makes up a significant portion of the overall surface area [36,37]. Previous work has shown that OH* groups can effectively enhance the catalytic performance of Fe-based catalysts, but investigating the mechanism of OH* action via experimental means presents certain difficulties. This is because the ligand clusters used for modification contain multiple OH* groups, and the coverage of OH* can significantly affect the catalytic performance of the catalyst [27,38]. Existing research indicates that OH* can promote the formation of CH3OH; therefore, studying the reaction mechanisms of CO2 hydrogenation to CH4 and CH3OH on the Fe5C2(510) surface under different OH coverages through theoretical calculations holds certain guiding significance for the experimental preparation of efficient catalysts [39]. In this study, we use spin-polarized density-functional theory (DFT) calculations to investigate the mechanisms of CO2 adsorption, H adsorption, CO2 and H co-adsorption on Fe5C2(510). CO2 dissociation, as well as surface CO2 hydrogenation to form CH4 and CH3OH are systematically studied at different OH* coverages. All feasible adsorption sites for CO2, H, and OH on the surface are considered to identify the most stable adsorption configurations in all co-adsorption states. Then, we investigate the elementary reactions of CH4 and CH3OH formation with varying amounts of OH adsorption. To provide more detailed suggestions for experimental trials, the surface reduction and doping by altering the coverage of H are further investigated. 2 Methods and models 2.1 Methods Spin-polarized density functional theory calculations were performed using the Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) [40,41]. Electron-ion interactions were described by projector-augmented wave potentials (PAW) [42,43]. Exchange-correlation effects were described by the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional and generalized gradient approximation (GGA) [44,45]. The plane wave cutoff energy was specified to be 400 eV, and electron smearing via a 2nd-order Methfessel-Paxton [46] technique with a width of 0.2 eV was employed to ensure energy with errors <1 meV per atom. The convergence criteria for electronic self-consistent interactions and forces were set to 10–4 eV and 0.03 eV/Å, respectively. Brillouin zone sampling was performed using the Monkhorst-Pack scheme [47]. To study the reactions, transition states (TSs) were estimated by the climbing image nudged elastic band (CI-NEB) method [48], and vibrational frequencies were analyzed to evaluate a transition state with only one imaginary frequency along with the reaction coordinate. Convergence tests for the relevant parameters are shown in Tables S1-S3 and Y. Comparison calculations were performed with spin polarization density functional theory methods implemented in the Device Studio program [49], which provides several functions for performing visualization, modeling, and simulation. The band structure and density of states simulation using the DS-PAW software is integrated into Device Studio [50]. The adsorption energy (E ads) of the surface species is calculated by: E ads = E species+surface - E surface - E species. ΔEm represents the energy change caused by configuration migration. ΔE represents the energy difference between two different adsorption configurations. ΔE a and ΔE r represent the changes in activation energy and reaction energy, respectively. ΔE dis represents the desorption energy required for the desorption of product A* from the surface to form A(g). where E species+surface is the total energy of the adsorbed species with catalyst, E surface and E species represent the energy of the unoccupied surface and species in the gas phase, respectively. Since OH* cannot exist independently in molecular form, the adsorption energy of OH* adsorbed on the surface is calculated as: E ads (OH*)=E species (OH*)+surface-(E (H2O)−1/2E (H2))-E surface. 2.1.1 Models For the Fe5C2(510) surface model, we used the same slab as our former study (Fig. 1 ) [30]. The p(2 × 2) supercells containing five carbon and three iron atom layers with a thickness of 5.18 Å were used (Fig. S2). The slab has a size of 9.96 Å × 12.64 Å, in which the top three atom layers with adsorbates are relaxed and the bottom five atom layers are fixed in their bulk position. According to the lattice sizes, 2 × 2 × 1 k-point grid sampling within the Brillouin zones was set. The vacuum gap space was set as 15 Å to avoid significant interactions between the two slabs. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Adsorption on Fe5C2(510) surface Fig. 1 depicts the optimal structure of the Fe5C2(510) surface and lists all potential adsorption sites and the surface cell's lattice parameters are given in Table S4. Two iron regions are interspersed on the surface. Fe atoms exhibit strong interactions with adsorbates like CO2 and CO [51]. The first stage of CO2 activation is the adsorption. We built every potential adsorption structure (Fig. S3). After optimization, nine locations on the surface of Fe5C2(510) are capable of steady CO2 adsorption (Fig. S4). Including five bridge sites (2F), three 3-fold sites (3F), and one 4-fold site (4F). Table 1 displays the appropriate structural characteristics and adsorption energies, and the configuration for CO2 adsorption is dominated by 2F sites. These 2F sites are primarily found between Fe#12, Fe#13, Fe#5, and Fe#6 atoms. In our investigation, the adsorption of CO2 on the Fe region of the Fe5C2(510) surface is more stable than that on the C region, which is consistent with the conclusion of previous work. As shown in Table 1, the calculated CO2 adsorption energy ranges from −1.01 eV to −0.10 eV. CO2 preferentially adsorbs at the 2F-4 site, with the C-O bonds elongated to 1.264 Å and 1.256 Å, compared to 1.177 Å in the gas phase CO2 (Fig. S5). The adsorption energy difference was determined by VASP and DS-PAW software giving a range from −0.12 eV to 0.08 eV. Overall consistency can be seen in the adsorption stability trend calculated by the two programs (Tables S5–S7, Figs. S6–S10). The 2F-4 bridged coordination sites are composed of Fe#5-Fe#13 atoms. The second stable CO2 adsorption configuration is a 3-fold site composed of Fe#5-Fe#12-Fe#13 sites, whose C-O bonds are 1.371 Å and 1.264 Å. In this work, we selected the 2F-4 site to explore the CO2 activation pathway on the surface of Fe5C2(510), and we also compared a portion of the research on the CO2 hydrogenation energy pathway with the earlier studies [10]. For H2 dissociation on the Fe5C2(510) surface, the small reaction energy barrier from H2 to 2H needs to be overcome [52]. Then two hydrogen atoms adsorb on the surface at various adsorption sites. The two H atoms are adsorbed by the combination of ortho or meta sites, and all feasible adsorption configurations have been built (Fig. S11). At 12 locations on the Fe5C2 (510) surface, the dissociated H2 could have been steadily adsorbed after optimization (Fig. S12). The calculated 2H adsorption energy on the surface of Fe5C2(510) was changed from −0.94 eV to −1.53 eV. On the most stable adsorption configuration of 2H on the Fe5C2(510) surface, two H atoms adsorbed at the 3F sites. The most stable CO2 and H2 adsorption configurations are both in the Fe region on the surface, and the least stable and sub-least stable CO2 and H2 co-adsorption configurations are both in the C region. To create the surface co-adsorption states, different equivalent symmetry sites of the most sTable 2H and CO2 adsorption configurations are chosen. The most stable CO2 adsorption configuration on the surface of Fe5C2(510) has two equivalent symmetry sites (Fe#5-Fe#13 and Fe#1-Fe#11), and the two H atoms dissociated by H2 have four adsorption combinations at their symmetry sites, all the 2H and CO2 co-adsorption combinations were optimized to yield six stable existing adsorption configurations. As illustrated in Fig. 2 , six adsorption configurations' adsorption energies are −1.76 eV (Fig. 2 a), −2.46 eV (Fig. 2b), −2.34 eV (Fig. 2c), −2.81 eV (Fig. 2d), −2.75 eV (Fig. 2e), and −2.10 eV (Fig. 2f). Among these six co-adsorption arrangements, Fig. 2 d shows the most stable one, in which two H atoms and CO2 are dispersedly adsorbed on the surface of Fe5C2(510). The fluctuation of this adsorption energy demonstrates that the degree of dispersion also has a major impact on the stability of the adsorption on the surface, in addition to the proximity to the surface, the axis bias angle, and the ambient Fe density. Successfully minimizing the impact of the lateral interaction through improved dispersion can increase the adsorption stability of the surface species. Apart from the reactants and products of the CO2 hydrogenation process, we also looked into the adsorption of all potential intermediate species on the surface, including O*, OH*, H2O*, CO x *, CH x *, H x CO*, H x COH*, and COH* (Fig. S13). The stable adsorption configurations were achieved after optimizing these species, which coincides with the findings of Pham et al. [36]. The CO2 conversion process results in the formation of O* species, and the hydrogenation of O* results in the formation of OH* and H2O. The adsorption stability impacts the efficacy of the active site, as well as the reaction pathway [53]. The optimization produced 13 and 9 stable adsorption configurations for O* and OH*, respectively (Figs. S14 and S15). The two most stable adsorption configurations for O* and OH* both formed three-fold sites on the surface. The gradual migration of C* to the gas phase during the hydrogenation to form CH4 indicates the weak adsorption of CH4 on the surface. The coordination of O atoms to Fe atoms with an adsorption energy of −1.69 eV forms the top adsorption for the CH3OH molecule. 3.2 CO2 initial hydrogenation pathway on pure Fe5C2(510) surface CO2 initial conversion over Fe5C2(510) surfaces involves three possible pathways: direct dissociation of CO2 to CO, hydrogenation of CO2 to form HCOO* intermediates, or formation of COOH* intermediates. Furthermore, these intermediates can be generated by additional cracking of the C-O bond and hydrogenation, resulting in a succession of C1 intermediates. As illustrated in Fig. 3 , the combination of these options results in six CO2 activation routes, which are the possible beginning pathways for CO2-FTS. In the RWGS process, CO2 is first adsorbed (CO2*) and activated. These CO2* can dissociate or be hydrogenated to generate COOH* intermediates, which can then be further converted to CO through the RWGS-MeOH (CO2 + H2 → CO + H2O; CO + 2H2 → CH3OH) pathway. COOH* species are separated into OH* and CO* species. OH* then undergoes hydrogenation to produce H2O*, while CO* either desorbs to generate gaseous CO or undergoes additional FTS reactions. Direct CO dissociation produces the species C* and O*, which can then be further hydrogenated to form CH x* (x = 1–4) and OH* or H2O*, respectively. The creation of CH x* species, which are the building blocks for the synthesis of hydrocarbons, begins with the hydrogenation, dissociation, and dehydration of HCO* and COH* intermediates. CH x* undergoes further coupling to produce hydrocarbon compounds [33]. CO2 activation on the Fe5C2(510) surface was studied in this work. The energy and structural parameters for all states are displayed in Fig. 4 , and the energy data is also given in the supporting information (Table S8). It is energetically unfavorable for COOH* formation because of a high activation energy of 1.15 eV and an endothermic reaction energy of 0.79 eV. Additionally, HCOO* intermediates can be created when the surface H* attacks the C atom of CO2 with an activation energy of 0.87 eV and an endothermic reaction energy of 0.45 eV. For the direct CO2 dissociation, the activated C-O bond length of the transition state is 1.56 Å, and the O atoms move to the nearby hollow fourfold site (Fe#3, Fe#4, Fe#5, and Fe#6) to reach the final state (Fig. S16) [52]. The direct dissociation of CO2 has an activation energy of 0.74 eV, which is kinetically more advantageous in comparison to CO2 dissociation through the formation of COOH* or HCOO* intermediates. The process is exothermic by 1.15 eV, which is thermodynamically beneficial too. The results are generally consistent with the findings of Wang et al. [54]. The CO desorption energy in the CO* and O* co-adsorption state is −2.28 eV, but the activation energies of the O* hydrogenation to produce OH* and the CO* hydrogenation to produce HCO* in this state are 1.08 eV and 1.20 eV, respectively, and are both lower than the energy needed for CO desorption (Fig. S17). This suggests that CO* is a highly likely intermediate for the conversion of CO2 on the iron carbide catalyst. Therefore, as shown in Fig. 4, we further investigated the energy pathway of CO activation and hydrogenation to produce CH4 and CH3OH on the surface. As shown in Figs. 5 and 6 , CO on the Fe5C2(510) surface can produce CH4 through multiple paths. CO* → HCO* → H2CO* → H2C* → H3C* → H4C* is the energetically preferred path. The formation of H2C* intermediate through HC* hydrogenation has a low activation energy of 0.79 eV, but the H2C* to H3C* step has a high activation energy of 1.22 eV, indicating that H2C* could be a significant intermediate in the CO2 hydrogenation process. CO* → HCO* → H2CO* → H3CO* → H3COH* is the energetically preferred path for CH3OH production. The H3CO* to H3COH* step has a high activation reaction energy of 1.43 eV, which makes the CO hydrogenation to CH3OH have less energy advantage. The surface C* created by direct CO dissociation creates a stable adsorption on the hollow four-fold site (4F-1, Fig. 5), whereas the surface C* formed by H-assisted CO dissociation by formation CHO* intermediate dissociation route forms a stable adsorption on the three-fold site (3F-2, Fig. 5). At these two locations, we compared the configurations and energy of all intermediate C* hydrogenation to CH4 processes. The findings demonstrate that the formation of CH2*and CH4* intermediate reaction steps at the 4F-1 site need to overcome activation energy barriers of 1.05 and 1.28 eV, respectively. While the corresponding intermediate reaction steps at the 3F-2 site have activation energies of 0.44 eV and 0.83 eV, respectively. Comparing the activation energy and migration energy required for the hydrogenation of CHx* species at the two sites, the energy path of CH2* hydrogenation to CH4* in the main reaction path is CH2* (3F-2) → CH2* (4F-1) → CH3* (3F-2) → CH4* (4F-1). As shown in Fig. 7 , at the 3F-2 site, the intermediate reaction step of CH3* production must overcome a significant activation reaction energy barrier of 1.22 eV, but at the 4F-1 site, this step only has to overcome an activation energy barrier of 0.62 eV. At the two sites, surface C* hydrogenation to CH4 proceeds in a different number of steps, and with different intermediate reactions with high activation energies, the surface C atoms at the 3F-2 site being hydrogenated to CH4 is easier overall. though Hydrogenation of dissociated C at 3F-2 and 4F-1 site on Fe5C2(510) surface. As shown in Fig. S13, among all the OH adsorption sites, the most stable configuration is on the 3F-3 site with an adsorption energy of about −1.70 eV. The adsorption at the 2F-1 site, with an adsorption energy of −1.69 eV, is the second stable adsorption configuration. We first investigated the barrier for the surface hydrogenation of O* to OH*. Then we computed the production of H2O* on Fe5C2(510). As shown in Fig. 8 , generating H2O though the OH* + OH* → H2O* + O* pathway has the lowest activation energy, which is 0.77 eV. The barrier for hydrogenating O* to OH* is 0.95 eV, while the barrier for hydrogenating OH* to generate H2O* is 1.56 eV, this is consistent with our previous research findings [30,54]. Existing research results indicate that on surfaces with high hydrogen coverage, H2O* preferentially forms via the pathway OH* + H* → H2O*. However, in real reactions, the hydrogen coverage on the surface is typically high [55,56]. The high coverage of OH* on the carbide surface is caused by the strong adsorption energy of OH* and the high hydrogenation barrier of OH* to H2O*, which could cause an impact on the creation of C2+ hydrocarbons [51,54]. It demonstrates that in the real reaction, it is easy for OH* and H2O* to co-adsorb with other surface species. The impact of H2O adsorption on the surface on the CO2 hydrogenation reaction of Fe-based catalysts has been the subject of several experimental and theoretical research, the hydrophilic surface will inhibit the secondary hydrogenation of the surface and promote chain growth [57]. However, the active sites on the catalyst surface will be occupied by the high coverage of H2O, which will hinder the catalyst's performance [58]. We investigated the mechanism of the CO2 hydrogenation process on the surface of Fe5C2(510) with OH co-adsorption. Fig. S18 depicts the optimum stable structure of the Fe5C2(510) surface with various OH coverages [59]. We investigated the CO2 activation mechanism of the Fe5C2(510) surface at four coverages (1 OH* to 4 OH* co-adsorption states). Since 20 Fe and 7 C atoms make up the top layer of the Fe5C2(510) surface, and with the increasing of OH coverage, 3, 5, 7, and 9 Fe atoms are coordinated with OH* The corresponding OH coverage is therefore nominated as 3/27, 5/27, 7/27 and 9/27 ML, respectively. The θ OH represents the surface OH coverage [60,61]. On the surface with 3/27 ML OH coverage, we investigated four potential routes for the initial dissociation of CO2 on the surface in the co-adsorption state of OH*, including CO2 direct dissociation, CO2 dissociation by formation COOH* or HCOO* intermediates, and hydrogenation of co-adsorbed OH*. Fig. 9 depicts the configurations and energies of the initial state, transition state, and final state of dissociated CO2, The formation COOH* intermediate has the lowest activation energy, which is 0.42 eV. The reaction has an exothermic reaction energy of 0.10 eV. The formation of HCOO* intermediate has an activation energy of 0.50 eV and a high exothermic reaction energy of 1.23 eV. These two reactions could take place simultaneously. Compared with that on the pure surface, the activation energy for the formation of COOH* intermediates dropped from 1.15 eV to 0.42 eV, and the activation energy of HCOO* formation dropped from 0.87 eV to 0.50 eV, while CO2 direct dissociation barrier increased from 0.74 eV to 0.85 eV. Surface OH* easily undergoes hydrogenation to generate H2O in the co-adsorption state, with a reaction activation energy of 0.44 eV. The difference is merely 0.02 eV when compared to the activation energy needed to create COOH* intermediates. As an alkaline group, OH* can reduce the adsorption of H2 and olefins and increase the adsorption of the acidic gas CO2. CO2 is more likely to dissociate via the H-assisted pathway in the OH* co-adsorption state. On the surface of Fe5C2(510) with 3/27 ML OH coverage, the pathways of CO2 hydrogenation to CH4 and CH3OH were also examined. The H2O produced during the CO2 hydrogenation reaction was desorbed into the vacuum layer to more accurately compare the impact of OH on the reaction. As seen in Fig. 10 , the process for the direct dissociation of CO2 happened along the direction of CO2* → CO* → HCO*, and the surface O* tends to be hydrogenated to produce OH*. However, compared to other reactions, OH* hydrogenation does not have the energy advantage. On CO* + O* + OH* + 2H* and CO* + 2OH* + H* co-adsorbed surfaces, CO desorption requires 2.29 eV and 1.55 eV, respectively, and does not have an energy advantage over the subsequent CO activation. The direct CO dissociation, the dissociation of H-assisted CO through intermediates of HCO* and COH*, as well as the route of OH* hydrogenation to H2O* are the four probable reaction pathways on the CO* + 2OH* + H* co-adsorption stage. The activation energies are 1.95 eV, 0.75 eV, 1.94 eV, and 0.86 eV, respectively. There is a kinetic benefit to H-assisted CO dissociation via the HCO* intermediate. For H-assisted CO2 dissociation by the formation of the HCOO* intermediate, further hydrogenation of the HCOO* intermediate can produce HCOOH* and H2COO* intermediates. It is challenging for the reactions to take place with activation energy barriers of 1.45 eV and 1.61 eV, respectively. The HCOOH* intermediate will continue to break down into HCO* and OH* intermediates even if the reaction takes place. For H-assisted CO2 dissociation by the formation of the COOH* intermediate, it is possible to further hydrogenate for the COOH* intermediates to produce HCOOH* intermediates, as well as to separate them into CO* and OH* intermediates. The reactions have an activation energy of 0.38 eV and 0.75 eV, respectively. The activation of CO2 on the surface of Fe5C2(510) with 3/27 ML OH coverage leads to the HCO* + 2OH* intermediates through different pathways. So, we further explore the reactions originated from HCO* + 2OH* intermediates to produce CH3OH and CH4 (Figs. 11 , S19, and Table. S9). Compared to the pure surface, the major product of CO2 hydrogenation shifted from CH4 to CH3OH on the Fe5C2(510) surface with 3/27 ML OH* coverage. The energetically preferred pathway for the formation of CH3OH* is CO2* → COOH* → CO* → HCO* → H2CO* → H3CO* → H3COH*. The H3CO* + H* → H3COH* reaction is the rate-determining step for the synthesis of CH3OH, and its activation energy is 0.92 eV. The energetically preferred pathway for the formation of CH4 is CO2* → COOH* → CO* → HCO* → H2CO*→ H2C* → H3C* → H4C*. The H3C* + H* → CH4* reaction is the rate-determining step in CH4 synthesis, and its activation energy is 0.81 eV. On the Fe5C2(510) surface with 3/27 ML OH coverage, the energetically preferred pathway of CH4 and CH3OH* formation is essentially identical as compared to the pure surface. 3.3 Surface with 5/27 to 9/27ML OH* coverage The energy and configurations of the initial state, final state, and transition state of CO2 hydrogenation on the Fe5C2(510) surface with 5/27 OH* ML coverage are shown in Fig. 12 . The primary route for the dissociation of CO2 is through the formation of HCOO* with an activation energy of 0.85 eV. There are two OH* on the surface of Fe5C2(510) with a 5/27 OH* ML coverage. Among them, the hydrogenation of OH* adsorbed at the 3F-2 site to produce H2O has a low activation energy barrier of 0.54 eV and an exothermic reaction energy of 0.23 eV, which has the lowest activation barrier. After H2O desorption, the surface of Fe5C2(510) with a 3/27 OH* coverage was recovered, and the subsequent reaction on the Fe5C2(510) surface with 5/27 OH* coverage is the same as that on the Fe5C2(510) surface with 3/27 OH* coverage. CO2 activation is also investigated on the Fe5C2(510) surface with 7/27 ML and 9/27 ML OH* coverages (Figs. S20 and S21). The energy priority of the three pathways is consistent with the surface with 5/27 ML OH* coverage, that is, the H-assisted path through the HCOO* intermediate. The primary difference is that compared to the pure surface, greater dissociation barriers must be overcome on the surfaces with 7/27 ML and 9/27 ML OH* coverages. It is demonstrated that the surface with high OH* coverage is not favorable for the occurrence of the CO2 hydrogenation reaction, which is consistent with the findings of former experimental research [64,65]. The reason is that OH* resides at the active site of Fe5C2(510) and interferes with the migration of the H atom. We compare the activation energy and reaction energy of CO2 activation on various OH* coverage surfaces. As shown in Fig. 13 , when surface OH coverage rises, the activation energy barrier for CO2 direct dissociation correspondingly increases. On the 3/27 ML OH* coverage surface, the dissociation barriers of H-assisted CO2 dissociation through HCOO* and COOH* intermediates are significantly lower than that on the pure surface, and H-assisted CO2 dissociation through COOH* intermediates is favorable. The dissociation barriers of H-assisted CO2 dissociation through HCOO* and COOH* intermediates increase on the Fe5C2(510) surface with 5/27 ML OH* coverage compared to the surface with 3/27 ML OH* coverage, yet it still has advantages over the pure surface. The activation energy barriers of CO2 dissociation on the Fe5C2(510) surface with 7/27 and 9/27 ML OH* coverages are higher than those on the pure surface. With the increase of OH* coverage, the preferential dissociation way of CO2 changed from direct dissociation way to H-assisted CO2 dissociation by forming the COOH* and HCOO* intermediates, indicating that the surface OH* changes the reaction mechanisms. The activation energy of the intermediate formation in the energetically preferred pathway of CH4 and CH3OH production on the pure surface and the 3/27 ML OH* coverage Fe5C2(510) surface is compared in Table 2 . On the pure surface, CO2* → CO* → HCO* → H2CO* → H2C* → H3C* → H4C* and CO2* → CO* → HCO* → H2CO* → H3CO* → H3COH* are the preferred pathways, respectively. On the Fe5C2(510) surface with 3/27 ML OH coverage, CO2* → CO* → HCO* → H2CO* → H2COH* → H2C* → H3C* → H4C* and CO2* → CO* → HCO* → H2CO* → H3CO* → H3COH* are the preferred pathways for the formation of CH4 and CH3OH, respectively. On the pure surface, H2CO* tends to dissociate into CH2* species directly. While on the surface with 3/27 ML OH* coverage, H2CO* is more likely to generate H2COH* before dissociating into CH2* species. The calculation findings demonstrate that all elementary reactions in the energetically preferred pathway on the surface with 3/27 ML OH* coverage have lower activation energies, especially for HCO*, H3COH*, and H2C* intermediates. The direct dissociation of H2CO* to H2C* is more beneficial on a clean surface. But on the surface of Fe5C2(510) with 3/27 OH* coverage, the hydrogenation of H2CO* to H3CO* takes place more efficiently. As a result, the primary reaction product changes. To enhance the performance of the catalyst by rational design of the catalyst, it is essential to accurately manage the coverage and adsorption stability of OH* on the surface of Fe5C2(510). 3.4 Control of surface OH* coverage Surface O* is reduced by H* to generate OH*, which is then further reduced to H2O*. The surface reduction efficiency of the catalyst may be altered by adjusting the surface H* amount, which will affect the generation of surface OH*. On the Fe5C2(510) surface with various H* coverages, we investigated the pathways of O* hydrogenation to OH* and H2O* (Fig. 14 ) [62]. When the surface H* is lowly covered on the surface, the reduction ability is relatively weak, and the activation energy of O* hydrogenation to OH* reaction is around 1 eV. As the surface H* coverage gradually increases, the reduction ability gradually increases, and the activation energy of O* hydrogenation to OH* reaction markedly decreases. This encourages the further reduction of OH* intermediates, and also the production of H2O*. The difference in activation energy between the formation of OH* and H2O is greatest when H* coverage reaches 7/27. The activation energy of the O* hydrogenation is the lowest (0.22 eV), indicating that the Fe5C2(510) surface with 7/27 H* atoms is the most favorable for OH* production. The corresponding structures are given in the supporting information (Figs. S22 and S23) 4 Conclusion Spin-polarized density-functional theory calculations have been used to investigate the adsorption of CO2, the adsorption of H, the co-adsorption of CO2 and H, the dissociation of CO2, and the mechanism of CO2 hydrogenation to form CH4 and CH3OH on the Fe5C2(510) surface with different OH* coverages. Both CO2 and H* are preferentially adsorbed in the Fe region. The most stable CO2 adsorption occurs at the bridge site. The degree of dispersion among the surface-adsorbed species determines the stability of the adsorption of the surface species when CO2 and H are co-adsorbed. On the pure Fe5C2(510) surface, CO2 preferentially dissociates via direct dissociation, and the major C1 species generated is CH4. Calculations were made for all potential hydrogenation reaction steps involving the oxygenated intermediates, demonstrating that OH* is a stable species on the surface. The mechanisms of CO2 hydrogenation to CH4 and CH3OH on Fe5C2(510) surfaces with different OH coverages were investigated. When the OH* surface coverage was changed from 0 ML to 3/27 ML, the preferential pathway for CO2 dissociation changed from CO2 direct dissociation to H-assisted CO2 dissociation by the formation of COOH* intermediates. The major C1 product of the reaction in this state is CH3OH. Notedly, the 3/27 ML OH* coverage favors the CO2 hydrogenation reaction. When the surface OH* coverage exceeds 3/27 ML, CO2 preferentially dissociates through the H-assisted CO2 dissociation by the formation of HCOO* intermediates. The CO2 dissociation and activation barriers tended to rise when the surface OH* coverage rose from 3/27 ML to 9/27 ML. It appears that high OH* coverage suppresses the CO2 hydrogenation reaction activity. To design the iron-based catalysis system with specific product distribution, maintaining the surface environment with OH* and H* could be an indispensable measure. coredata.dc:description: The conversion of CO2 into high-value-added chemicals via the Fischer-Tropsch Synthesis (FTS) reaction has gathered a lot of attention. The surface oxygenation environment is a significant factor affecting the catalyst performance. In this work, spin-polarized density-functional theory calculations have been used to investigate the adsorption and reactions of CO2 and H to generate CH4 and CH3OH on Fe5C2(510) surfaces with varying OH* coverage. On the pure Fe5C2(510) surface, CO2 preferentially dissociates via direct dissociation, and the major C1 species generated is CH4. At low OH* coverage, the preferential pathway for CO2 dissociation changes from direct dissociation to the H-assisted route by the formation of COOH*. The major C1 product of the reaction in this state is transferred to CH3OH. In addition, CO2 hydrogenation reactions are facilitated by the OH* species. At high OH coverage, CO2 preferentially dissociates through the HCOO* intermediates. However, it appears that the CO2 hydrogenation reaction activity is suppressed. The results demonstrate that maintaining the surface environment with OH* and H* could be an indispensable measure to obtain the target product in the iron-based CO2 Fischer-Tropsch Synthesis system.
coredata.dc:title: Mechanistic insights of surface OH* modulation on methanol production with CO2 hydrogenation by iron-based catalyst
